result.hateful_meaning: A non-Jewish woman. Derived from the Hebrew root Shin-Qof-Tzadei, meaning loathsome or abomination. Most commonly used to refer to a non-Jewish woman who is dating or married to a Jewish man.
A person of Asian descent, particularly Vietnamese or Chinese.
A person of Asian origin (Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese etc.) Derived from the term for those who have epicanthic folds.
A white Australian, alluding to Skippy the Bush Kangaroo, a once-popular Australian television show for children.
result.nonhateful_meaning: [1] Avoid [2] A form of walking [3] A boat

result.hateful_meaning: A Caucasian
Derogatory term for a person from the Middle East, Arab, South Asian world
In Australia, an Aboriginal woman.

A person of Italian birth or descent. Most likely derived from 'Guinea Negro,' implying that Italians are dark or swarthy-skinned like the natives of Guinea. The diminutive 'Ginzo' probably dates back to World War II and is derived from Australian slang picked up by US servicemen in the Pacific Theater.

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.
A person of Asian origin (Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Vietnamese etc.) Derived from the term for those who have epicanthic folds.
Considered a slur when used by non-Italians to describe an Italian.
A black person.

A foreigner; especially used disparagingly against North Americans and North Europeans in Latin America. (Likely from the Spanish word 'griego', meaning Greek. The use of the term Greek for something foreign or unintelligible is also seen in the similar expression 'it's Greek to me'.) The term lends itself to derogatory or paternalistic connotations, but in most of the contexts it may not be meant pejoratively.

A foreigner; especially used disparagingly against North Americans and North Europeans in Latin America. (Likely from the Spanish word 'griego', meaning Greek. The use of the term Greek for something foreign or unintelligible is also seen in the similar expression 'it's Greek to me'.) The term lends itself to derogatory or paternalistic connotations, but in most of the contexts it may not be meant pejoratively.

A Welsh person. First used ca. 17th century. From the River Taff or the Welsh pronunciation of the name David (in Welsh, Dafydd). Children's rhyme: 'Taffy was a Welshman, Taffy was a thief'. Generally considered offensive when used by an English person.
result.nonhateful_meaning: [1] A person's name [2] A type of candy

result.hateful_meaning: A term used ambiguously in southern Oregon directed towards the Klamath people during a dispute over the sucker fish of the Klamath River which was considered sacred by the tribe. Troublemakers displayed bumper-stickers with the message 'Save a Farmer, Fillet a sucker fish.'
A British person, derived from the Black and Tans, the nickname for an auxiliary British Army unit deployed to Ireland in the 1920s and which gained a reputation for brutality.
A word used in Mexico to denote a person of fair complexion or with blond or red hair
A black child.
A black person. [19th century]

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.

[1] A Romani people. [2] Egyptians. These are variations of 'Gypsy', the most common word in English for people of Romani origin. 'Gypsy' is not in itself an ethnic slur but its usage is sometimes controversial.

[1] An inconsequential person (typically lower class). [2] A Gypsy. [3] In Scotland, a member of the native community previously itinerant (but mainly now settled) who were reputed for their production of domestic implements from basic materials and for repair of the same items, being also known in the past as 'travelling tinsmiths'. The slur is possibly derived from a reputation for rowdy and alcoholic recreation. Often wrongly confused with Gypsy/Romany people.
Considered a slur when used by non-Italians to describe an Italian.

Pejorative term used in south of Mainland China and Hong Kong to denote a white man. Loosely translated as 'foreign devil;' more literally, might be 'ghost dude/bloke/guy/etc.' Gwei means 'ghost.' The color white is associated with ghosts in China. A lo is a regular guy (i.e. a fellow, a chap, or a bloke). Once a mark of xenophobia, the word is now in general, informal use but still considered derogatory.
Denotes a person that is half African.
Used for any Germanic people, including the Dutch and Flemish.
A non-native, used by Hawaiians mainly to refer to whites (less commonly to refer to non-Hawaiians). Can be used neutrally, dependent on context.
A Tamil.

Helga from German name Helga. It is a term to describe a German woman, usually tall, blue-eyed, blond and strongly built, which are considered typical physical features of German women. It also implies the negative opinion about this kind of look.
A rural person.
A Jewish person, derived from the word 'Hebrew'.
A black person.

[1] An inconsequential person (typically lower class). [2] A Gypsy. [3] In Scotland, a member of the native community previously itinerant (but mainly now settled) who were reputed for their production of domestic implements from basic materials and for repair of the same items, being also known in the past as 'travelling tinsmiths'. The slur is possibly derived from a reputation for rowdy and alcoholic recreation. Often wrongly confused with Gypsy/Romany people.
result.nonhateful_meaning: To experiment or attempt to fix

result.hateful_meaning: [1] An inconsequential person (typically lower class). [2] A Gypsy. [3] In Scotland, a member of the native community previously itinerant (but mainly now settled) who were reputed for their production of domestic implements from basic materials and for repair of the same items, being also known in the past as 'travelling tinsmiths'. The slur is possibly derived from a reputation for rowdy and alcoholic recreation. Often wrongly confused with Gypsy/Romany people.
A person of German descent.
A derogatory term for Afrikaners
German slang for a British person, particular a soldier.

A white person. Derived from an African-American pronunciation of 'hunky', the disparaging term for a Hungarian laborer. The first record of its use as an insulting term for a white person dates from the 1950s.

[1] A German, especially a German soldier; popular during World War I. Derived from a speech given by Kaiser Wilhelm of Germany to the German contingent sent to China during the Boxer Rebellion in which he exhorted them to 'be like Huns' (i.e., savage and ruthless) to their Chinese enemy. [2] A Protestant in Northern Ireland. [3] A member of the British military in Ireland ('Britannia's huns').
result.nonhateful_meaning: An aggressive, Asian nomadic people from the 4th and 5th centuries

result.hateful_meaning: [1] A Hungarian. [2] A person of central or east European birth or descent.
A black Jew, from the combination of Hebrew and 'bro'.
A Caucasian of low class or limited income.
A person of mixed Hispanic and black parentage.

Szwab (plural szwaby; literally Swabian), is derogatory when referring to any Germans instead of just the inhabitants of Swabia. The origin of this usage remains unclear, as Swabia and Poland are relatively far apart.
A Jewish person (from Isaac and Moses).
A Jewish person (from Isaac and Moses).
A Jewish person (from Isaac and Moses).
German pejorative for an American.
[1] A Hungarian. [2] A person of central or east European birth or descent.
A Hungarian-Polish person.
Used by the Sinhala majority to refer to a person of Tamil origin from North (Jaffna). Refers to the excessive use of Thala Thel(or gingelly oil) by this community.

[1] A European American, with little or no social or blood links to any tribe, who claims to be an American Indian (Native American). [2] An Asian American who has become completely integrated into White American, or mainstream American culture.
A Jewish person, derived from the personal name Hyman (from the Hebrew name Chayyim). Jesse Jackson provoked controversy by referring to New York City as 'Hymietown' in 1984.
A black person.
A black person
A black person (referencing stereotypical hair type).
A black person. Jiggaboo or jigabo is from a Bantu verb tshikabo, meaning meek or servile.
A person of German descent, from sauerkraut.
A Muslim.
A Native American.
pejorative term used for Romanian Roma

A black person. The term may cause offense. though Randall Kennedy's Nigger: The Strange Career of a Troublesome Word notes that some judges have considered 'darky' a 'term of endearment.' In South Africa, it can be considered offensive (depending on the context), but is commonly used among black people to refer to other black people in a non-derogatory way.
A black person. Possibly from Portuguese barracco, a building constructed to hold slaves for sale (1837). Popularized by the song 'Zip Coon', played at Minstrel shows in the 1830s.
A black person.
Acronym for White Anglo-Saxton Protestant, and often synonymous with rectitude.
A British person, meaning 'island ape' or 'island monkey'.
A person from Pakistan or India named after traditional bread (chapati). This term is common among Polish immigrants in the UK
A person from Pakistan or India named after traditional bread (chapati). This term is common among Polish immigrants in the UK
A person from Pakistan or India named after traditional bread (chapati). This term is common among Polish immigrants in the UK
A black person.
result.nonhateful_meaning: A darkening of skin pigmentation due to exposure to the sun

result.hateful_meaning: A person with dark skin. Can refer to a person with African origin. This terms is also used by Sri Lankan diaspora living in USA to refer to an African American.
[1] A Caucasian trying to act black. [2] A black person trying to act Caucasian.
A person originating from the Indian subcontinent, used by native Malaysians and Indonesians.
A Vietnamese person, from the tunnels dug by the Viet Cong to elude pursuit during the Vietnam war.
An Irish Traveller.

[1] Used in 19th-century United States to refer to the Irish. [2] Sometimes used today in reference to white people in a manner similar to white trash or redneck. [3] Also refers to white youth that imitate urban black youth by means of clothing style, mannerisms, and slang speech. The 'w' at the start of wigger refers to the white person and the 'igger' refers to nigger, which is a racial slur for black people. [4] Also used by radical Quebecois in self-reference, as in the seminal 1968 book White Niggers of America.

[1] Used in 19th-century United States to refer to the Irish. [2] Sometimes used today in reference to white people in a manner similar to white trash or redneck. [3] Also refers to white youth that imitate urban black youth by means of clothing style, mannerisms, and slang speech. The 'w' at the start of wigger refers to the white person and the 'igger' refers to nigger, which is a racial slur for black people. [4] Also used by radical Quebecois in self-reference, as in the seminal 1968 book White Niggers of America.

[3] Also refers to white youth that imitate urban black youth by means of clothing style, mannerisms, and slang speech. The 'w' at the start of wigger refers to the white person and the 'igger' refers to nigger, which is a racial slur for black people. A Caucasian who emulates, or associates with, Chinese people.
result.nonhateful_meaning: A deliberate blink of one eye

result.hateful_meaning: A swarthy or dark-skinned foreigner. Possibly derived from 'golliwogg' In Britain, it usually refers to dark skinned people from Asia or Africa, though some use the term to refer to anyone outside the borders of their own country. In Australia the term 'wog' is usually used to refer to Mediterranean Europeans (Spaniards, Italians, and Greeks) although it can be used for some Eastern Europeans, particularly those of the Balkans (Bosnians, Macedonians, Serbians, Croatians, or Albanians).
A person of Italian descent, derived from the Italian dialectism, 'guappo,' close to 'dude, swaggerer' and other informal appellations, a greeting among male Neapolitans.
Kikuyu slur for a member of the Luo ethnic group, meaning 'uncircumcised'.
A person of mixed Caucasian and Mexican parentage.
A person of Asian descent.

A Jewish person, although it is an endonym among Yiddish-speaking Jews. (The term is also used positively in Britain for Tottenham Hotspur fans (often proudly by themselves, for example calling themselves 'the Yid Army'), which includes a large Jewish supporting base from north-east London.)
Italian word for a black person, from 'eggplant'.
Designation for a Buddhist or Buddhist property.
A person of Irish descent.
result.nonhateful_meaning: A mythical creature from Irish folklore

result.hateful_meaning: A person of mixed Caucasian and black parentage.
A black person, from the traditional statue.
A Polynesian.
A black person. Jiggaboo or jigabo is from a Bantu verb tshikabo, meaning meek or servile.

An Asian person. Used by American military personnel during the Korean War and Vietnam War. Also seen in the films Platoon, Apocalypse Now, Full Metal Jacket and Gran Torino. The phrase 'zips in the wire' from Platoon has also been used outside of this context.
result.nonhateful_meaning: [1] Go quickly [2] A fastener on an article of clothing

result.hateful_meaning: A Lithuanian, particularly a Lithuanian American.
Originally used by francophone colonialists in Central Africa's Belgian Congo to refer to the native population; use has expanded to other groups, including North Africans and Indians.
A person of Italian descent.
Born of a Spanish parent and a Native American parent, from the Spanish word for 'mixed'.
Italian word for a black person, from 'eggplant'.
Latino word for a black person.
